title: Operators call for calm amid Greek fiscal crisis
text:
Save 
Specialist tour operators have tried to reassure agents and holidaymakers in the wake of further uncertainty in Greece this week. 
The government has called a snap referendum on the latest bailout proposal from its lenders and as TTG went to press, Greece also looked like it was heading for a default on its €1.6 billion loan from the International Monetary Fund on Tuesday night. 
Sunvil and Abta chairman Noel Josephides, who is in Greece, told TTG that the country was still proving popular with tourists. 
“This morning we went on a Mount Athos cruise. The boat was full. There were 150-200 people on it. When we came back, another boat was going out full,” Josephides said. “There is no doubt that June is not as good as they [Greece] expected but we know that because we can see our figures.” 
He added: “Everybody here just looks flabbergasted when you explain to them what’s being said about things in England.” 
Although there is no limit for foreign withdrawals from cash machines, Sunvil and Olympic Holidays have put in place measures to offer funds to tourists in resort. 
Photis Lambrianides, commercial director at Olympic Holidays, said: “The enjoyment and wellbeing of tourists is not going to be affected.” 
He said Olympic would be able to cope if Greece exited the eurozone. 
He added: “If it does happen, it’s going to benefit tourists because effectively whatever currency they adopt, it will be devalued and the prices in resort will become cheaper and will benefit tourists.” 
Chris Wright, Sunvil’s managing director, said: “The main concern was because the banks were closed and the restaurants wouldn’t be able to buy food and that sort of thing. 
“Once we’d reassured them [customers] that all the restaurants were open and tourists can actually get cash out of the cash machines, then there wasn’t really an issue.” 
The Foreign Office has raised the possibility of more demonstrations and suggests travellers take enough cash to cover their stay. 
The UK arm of the Greek National Tourism Organisation said the Ministry for Economy, Infrastructure, Shipping and 
Tourism did not “anticipate any inconvenience in visitors’ everyday holiday experiences… as there are adequate fuel supplies, products and services.”
